The function is subjected to a Fourier transform, resulting in \\( \hat{z}(\omega) \\), where \\( \omega \\) is the frequency domain variable.

If the function \\( z(t) \\) is modified by adding a constant real value \\( a \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve naturally, will the Fourier transform \\( \hat{z}(\omega) \\) at any given \\( \omega \\) be equivalent to adding \\( a \\delta(\omega) \\) to the original \\( \hat{z}(\omega) \\) (where \\( \delta \\) is the Dirac delta function)?
Explanation: Adding a constant \\( a \\) to \\( z(t) \\) translates to adding a \\( a \\cdot \delta(\omega) \\) in the frequency domain, due to the Fourier transform properties. This perturbation translates linearly through the transform.
